articles.headline: A House Divided: A Palestinian, a Settler and the Struggle for East Jerusalem
articles.snippet: Efforts to force Palestinians from Sheikh Jarrah set the stage for the recent Gaza war. A similar dynamic looms in a nearby district.
articles.abstract: Efforts to force Palestinians from Sheikh Jarrah set the stage for the recent Gaza war. A similar dynamic looms in a nearby district.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Few places in East Jerusalem show the struggle over the city more intimately than a four-story house on a narrow alley in the Silwan district.

articles.headline: U.S. Seizes Share of Ransom From Hackers in Colonial Pipeline Attack
articles.snippet: Investigators traced 75 Bitcoins worth more than $4 million through nearly two dozen cryptocurrency accounts.
articles.abstract: Investigators traced 75 Bitcoins worth more than $4 million through nearly two dozen cryptocurrency accounts.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department said on Monday that it had seized much of the ransom that a major U.S. pipeline operator had paid last month to a Russian hacking collective, turning the tables on the hackers by reaching into a digital wallet to snatch back millions of dollars in cryptocurrency.
articles.byline: By Katie Benner and Nicole Perlroth

articles.headline: Alzheimer’s Drug Is Bonanza for Biogen, Most Likely at Taxpayer Expense
articles.snippet: Despite scant evidence that it works, the drug, Aduhelm, is predicted to generate billions of dollars in revenue, much of it from Medicare.
articles.abstract: Despite scant evidence that it works, the drug, Aduhelm, is predicted to generate billions of dollars in revenue, much of it from Medicare.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration’s decision on Monday to approve a new Alzheimer’s medication over the fierce objections of its scientific advisers sets into motion one of the most controversial drug introductions in years.
articles.byline: By Rebecca Robbins and Pam Belluck

articles.headline: Farewell, Millennial Lifestyle Subsidy
articles.snippet: The price for Ubers, scooters and Airbnb rentals is going up as tech companies aim for profitability.
articles.abstract: The price for Ubers, scooters and Airbnb rentals is going up as tech companies aim for profitability.
articles.lead_paragraph: A few years ago, while on a work trip in Los Angeles, I hailed an Uber for a crosstown ride during rush hour. I knew it would be a long trip, and I steeled myself to fork over $60 or $70.

articles.headline: China Is Trying to Tame Inflation. It Matters to Much of the Globe.
articles.snippet: Rising costs at its factories — an accelerating trend, new data showed — could trickle into the rest of the world economy.
articles.abstract: Rising costs at its factories — an accelerating trend, new data showed — could trickle into the rest of the world economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — Prices are jumping in the United States and around the world, prompting growing warnings that a wave of inflation could threaten the global economy if it persists.

articles.headline: The Criminals Thought the Devices Were Secure. But the Seller Was the F.B.I.
articles.snippet: Global law enforcement officials revealed a three-year operation in which they said they had intercepted over 20 million messages. Hundreds of arrests were made in more than a dozen countries.
articles.abstract: Global law enforcement officials revealed a three-year operation in which they said they had intercepted over 20 million messages. Hundreds of arrests were made in more than a dozen countries.
articles.lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — The cellphones, procured on the black market, performed a single function hidden behind a calculator app: sending encrypted messages and photos.
articles.byline: By Yan Zhuang, Elian Peltier and Alan Feuer

articles.headline: From Appetizers to Tuition, Incentives to Job Seekers Grow
articles.snippet: Employers are finding ways to get applicants in the door, and to retain employees once they’re hired.
articles.abstract: Employers are finding ways to get applicants in the door, and to retain employees once they’re hired.
articles.lead_paragraph: College subsidies for children and spouses. Free rooms for summer hotel employees and a set of knives for aspiring culinary workers. And appetizers on the house for anyone willing to sit down for a restaurant job interview.

articles.headline: Wealthiest Executives Paid Little to Nothing in Federal Income Taxes, Report Says
articles.snippet: An analysis by ProPublica based on I.R.S. documents showed billionaires like Jeff Bezos and Elon Musk benefited from tax code loopholes and a focus on taxing income over wealth.
articles.abstract: An analysis by ProPublica based on I.R.S. documents showed billionaires like Jeff Bezos and Elon Musk benefited from tax code loopholes and a focus on taxing income over wealth.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The 25 richest Americans, including Jeff Bezos, Michael Bloomberg and Elon Musk, paid relatively little — and sometimes nothing — in federal income taxes between 2014 and 2018, according to an analysis from the news organization ProPublica that was based on a trove of Internal Revenue Service tax data.
